data.name: Sum decomposition
data.description:
## Sum decomposition We can decompose given integer - *s*
to the sum of exactly    *n*    integers:   *x0,    x1,    x2,    ...    xn*    
where
`1 <= x0 < x1 < x2 < ... < xn <= k`

For example: ``` Given s=5, n=2, k=3 we can decompose s to the following sums: 1+4 = 5 (but 4>k=3) 2+3 = 5 3+2 = 5 (but 3>2) 4+1 = 5 (but 4<1) So the only way to decompose s=5 when to two numbers when k=3 is to make sum: [2, 3] ``` Sometimes there exist more than one way to decompose some sums: ``` Given s=4, n=2, k=7 we can decompose s to the following sums: 1+5 = 6 2+4 = 6 3+3 = 6 (but 3=3) 4+2 = 6 (but 4>2) 5+1 = 6 (but 5>1) So we are left with: [1, 5] and [2, 4] ``` And sometimes the decomposition could not be achieved: ``` Given s=10, n=20, k=100 there's no way to meet all the given conditions. ``` So now it's your task to write a function  `decomposeSum(n, k, sum)`  to generate all possible decompositions in lexicographical order: ``` [1,2,6] should be always before [1,3,5] and [2,3,4] ``` Your function should return sorted array of all sum decompositions: ``` E.g. decomposeSum for n=3, k=6 and s=10 should return: [[ 1, 3, 6 ], [ 1, 4, 5 ], [ 2, 3, 5 ]] ``` Good luck! :)
